description: How many total participants were recruited?
help: This is before any filtering based on speed, comprehension, etc.

description: How many participants were included in the final analysis (after filtering)?
How were participants recruited?
values: University Students; Linguistics Program; Online platform; Advertisement / Word of mouth; Mixed; Not Reported

description: How were participants compensated?
values: Paid directly; Credit; Incentive; Mixed; Not Reported
help: Credit is for students who received grades or course credits.

description: Which participant demographics were reported (check all that apply)?
values: Gender / Sex; Age; Education; Region; Language background; Other; Not Reported

description: What language was the study investigating (be as specific as possible)?
help: If possible include the terminology or level of granularity used by authors.

description: How many total separate JT experiments did the paper report?
help: This defaults to 1, but many papers report mure than one experiment. List the number of experiments *as described by the authors*.

description: What number (out of the total number of experiments) is this experiment?
help: Use numbers *as described by the authors*, e.g. 1, 2a, 2b, 3

description: How many factors were there in the design?
How many levels per factor? Code separately, e.g. A = 2; B = 3; …
What ware the total number of experimental conditions?
help: Each combination of factor and level is a condition. So a 2x3 design has 6 total conditions.

description: How were items counterbalanced for presentation?
values: Complete; Partial; Latin Square; Not Reported

description: Did the study use a **within-subjects** or **between-subjects** design?
help: Most studies are within-subjects designs, but some may examine different conditions or social groups.

description: If the study used a **between-subjects** design, what was the **comparison condition(s)**?
help: This is the condition against which groups of participants are compared. This could involve randomly assigned experimental conditions or demographic groups (e.g. gender, age, education level).

description: If the study used a between subjects design, was the number of participants balanced across conditions?
Were the stimili **balanced across acceptability levels**?
help: If the study has, e.g., 3 levels of acceptability, were there equal numbers of items for each level?

description: How were items randomized for presentation?
values: Block randomized; Fully randomized; Not Reported
help: Block randomization involves randomizing only within conditions. Fully randomized items are intermixed.

description: Did the study compare results of multiple judgment tasks **of the same items** to test different task features / conditions?
help: This is only "Yes" if the exact same items were involved in different tasks, e.g. forced choice vs. likert scale.

description: Number of **all items** including controls, fillers, or distractors:
Number of **target items** in judgment task not including fillers or distractors:
Number of **filler** or distractor items, if any:
help: Many older studies may not use fillers, or it may be unclear.

description: Number of **pre-test** items, if any:
help: These can be practice items or any other preparatory items.

description: Number of **post-test** items, if any:
help: This is uncommon, and we will assume a study did **not** include any if it is not mentioned.

description: What was the general level of linguistic phenomena investigated (syntax, morphology, lexis,…)?
values: Syntax; Morphology; Lexis; Semantics; Other; Not Reported
help: This may not be very clear, so aim for the most general level.

description: Were the items constructed by the researchers or based on authentic materials?
values: Fully Constructed; Fully Authentic; Edited Authentic; Not Reported
help: Typically these are fully constructed, but this is not often reported. "Edited authentic" is any item that was taken from natural corpora and then edited.

description: Were the items balanced for internal features, e.g. frequency, etc.?
values: Frequency; Length; Semantics; Other; Not Reported

description: Were **items pilot-tested** for plausibility?
help: This refers to testing of the sentences or phenomena being presented to participants, **not** to the task itself.

description: Were items presented with **additional context**?
help: This may include preceding or following text / audio, or items embedded within larger contexts (e.g. paragraphs). Isolated sentences are just coded as "No".

description: What **instructions** were given to the participants (copy verbatim if possible)?
help: If possible include the verbatim text used.

description: What **terminology** did the authors use to refer to their judgment task with participants?
values: acceptability; naturallness; grammaticality; appropriateness; probability; Not Reported
help: This is usually found in the instructions provided to participants.

description: What was the scale of participants' responses?
help: Forced choice studies are binary. Likert scales are ordinal, and other studies using thermometer ratings, points, sliders, or line marking are considered continuous.

description: How many levels of acceptability were used (2, 7, 100, …)?
help: Continuous scales often use 100. For visual estimation (putting marks on a line), put "0"

description: Were items evaluated in isolation or against a comparison item or baseline (e.g. magnitude estimation)?
values: Isolation; Magnitude Estimation; Variant Comparison; Not Reported
help: Most studies ask for evaluation in isolation. Magnitude estimation relies on comparison against a baseline item. Other studies many ask participants to choose between alternatives.

description: What modality was the judgment task delivered in?
values: Written; Audio; Visual (not written); Mixed; Not Reported
help: Typically these are in written text, but if this is not explicitly stated then we mark "Not Reported"

description: Were participants able to review and change their ratings?
help: Usually not, but this is seldom reported.

description: Were items presented in a fixed or variable amount of time, or was the presentation self-paced?
help: Some studies may use speeded judgment tasks. Most are self-paced but this is not always explicitly stated.

description: How were item responses recorded?
help: This is usually clear from how the study was distributed, but may not be as clear in older studies.

description: Was the task duration recorded?
help: Did the study mention how long participants took (usually as an average)?

description: Was the study conducted under supervision of the research (e.g. in a lab or with researcher present)?
Was any pilot-testing of the task conducted?
help: This is to assess the task, not the items (there is another code for that above).

description: Were participants asked to rate confidence of their responses?
What procedures were there for participant breaks?
help: Most studies are self-paced, and hence participants control their breaks, but this is rarely reported.

description: Were participants asked to answer comprehension question(s) during the study?
Was the response analysed as a continuous scale, an ordinal factor, or dichotomous value?
values: Continuous; Ordinal; Dichotomous; Other; Not Reported
help: Ordinal (Likert scale) data are often treated as continous variables for the purpose of analysis. This is usually evident in the statistical tests used, e.g. means/medians, t-tests or linear regression.

description: Was there any preprocessing of the ratings data, e.g. standardizaton or other transformations?
values: Z-score; Centering; Log Transform; Other; Not Reported
help: Any normalization, standardization, or manipulation of the raw data counts.

description: What software tools were used for analysis?
values: R; SPSS; Python; Other; Not Reported

description: What statistical methods were used to test hypotheses?
values: ANOVA; t-test; Regression; Mixed-Effects Regression; Other; Not Reported
help: This does **not** include summary descriptive statistics (mean, median, standard deviation,…)

description: Were adjustments made for by-participant or by-item variation ('random effects')?
values: Participant; Items; Other; None; Not Reported
help: Any statistical tests other than mixed-effects models do **not** do this, but this fact is not often reported.

description: Were effect sizes reported?
What was the threshold for statistical significance?
Were corrections for multiple comparisions made?
Was any power analysis conducted, before or after the study?
help: This is rare and will be explicitly mentioned if it is done.

description: Did researchers investigate autocorrelation of participants’ ratings?
help: Very rarely done

description: Did researchers investigate participants’ ratings propensity to rate higher or lower on average?
help: Very rarely done

description: Was other data not from a judgment rating task used to triangulate data from judgment task?
help: This can include other psycholinguistic data (response times, self-paced reading, lexical decision, sentence completion,...) or data from corpus frequencies or probabilities

description: If judgments were compared to other data, what kind of other data was used?
help: If not relevant, use "NA".

description: Are the **stimulus items and task** publicly available?
values: Published Article; Published Supplement; Public Repository; On Request; Not Reported
help: May need to be checked on publisher's site

description: Are the **data and code** for analysis publicly available?
values: Published Article; Published Supplement; Public Repository; On Request; Not Reported
help: May need to be checked on publisher's site

description: If items are published elsewhere, URL of location:
If data / code are published elsewhere, URL of location:
Additional notes, uncertainties, or observations by the coder.
